title: Contributing
text:
This is a community open source project to gather and share wisdom from the CZI EOSS Community. Organizational Mycology works to faciltiate theses resources on behalf of the EOSS Community.
We are looking for contributions that add topics and enhance our resources for the benefit of other Open Source Leaders.


By contributing, you agree that we may redistribute your work under our license
You agree to abide by the CZI Community Participation Guidelines in this space.



The easiest way to get started is to file an issue to tell us about a spelling mistake, some awkward wording, or a factual error. This is a good way to introduce yourself and to meet some of our community members.

If you do not have a [GitHub][github] account, you can [send us comments by email][contact]. However, we will be able to respond more quickly if you use one of the other methods described below.
If you have a [GitHub][github] account, or are willing to [create one][github-join], but do not know how to use Git, you can report problems or suggest improvements by [creating an issue][issues]. This allows us to assign the item to someone and to respond to it in a threaded discussion.
If you are comfortable with Git, and would like to add or change material, you can submit a pull request (PR).

This contributor guide was adapted from that of Software Carpentry, The Carpentries

title: Strategic Thinking Starter Kit for Open Source Projects
text:
A practical guide to help open source software projects think strategically, have productive conversations, and make values-aligned decisions
Based on insights from the CZI EOSS Community Call, March 27, 2025



This starter kit is designed to be flexible. You donâ€™t need to do everything at once, and you donâ€™t need formal strategic planning experience to benefit from thinking strategically.

Important Context: Open source projects are not corporations. Your strategic approach should reflect your community-centered values, volunteer dynamics, and the reality that leadership is often distributed. This guide embraces that complexity.



ğŸ¯ Quick Start Jump to the â€œDecision Toolsâ€ section when facing a specific choice (like evaluating a funding opportunity)
ğŸ’¬ Facilitation Use the â€œConversation Guidesâ€ to structure a strategic discussion with your team or community
ğŸ“š Deep Dive Read through all sections to build your strategic thinking foundation







Strategy is about leverageâ€”how to have the most impact with the resources you have. Itâ€™s a coherent story about how your project will succeed by solving a hard problem.

A strategy helps you answer two questions: 1. Where to play (what problem are we solving?) 2. How to win (what makes our approach work?)












Concept
What It Is
Example




Strategy
Your high-level approach and theory of changeâ€”the 1-page story of your success
â€œWeâ€™ll build excellent relationships with researchers while designing financially accessible tools for a global audienceâ€


Strategic Plan
A documented set of goals, priorities, and focus areas (typically 2-5 years)
â€œGoals: 1) Expand regional communities 2) Improve contributor onboarding 3) Diversify revenueâ€


Tactics
Specific methods and actions to implement your strategy
â€œHost monthly community calls,â€ â€œApply for X foundation grant,â€ â€œHire a community managerâ€






âœ… It defines what you wonâ€™t do Strategic â€œnoâ€™sâ€ are as important as â€œyesâ€™sâ€â€”they protect your focus and resources
âœ… It makes decision-making easier When team members can â€œtap the signâ€ and reference your strategy to guide choices
âœ… Itâ€™s grounded in constraints Your resources, capacity, and values shape whatâ€™s possibleâ€”embrace them as design inputs
âœ… It (can) fit on one page If you canâ€™t explain it simply, itâ€™s not clear enough to guide action
âœ… Itâ€™s living and adaptable More like gardening than engineeringâ€”you tend it and adjust as conditions change



Imagine someone writing a one-page story about your projectâ€™s success in 3-5 years. What would that story say? Try completing this template:
[Project Name] succeeded in [solving what hard problem].

They did this by focusing on [2-3 key focus areas].

This approach worked because [what made it effective/different].

They explicitly chose NOT to [what they said no to] so they could 
maintain focus.





One of the biggest questions in open source strategic planning is: â€œWho is â€˜the organizationâ€™?â€ Is it the core maintainers? All contributors? Funded staff? The broader community?

Thereâ€™s No Single Right Answer: Different levels of strategic work require different participants. The key is being intentional about whoâ€™s in the room for what kinds of discussions, and why.



Level 1: Core Strategy (Small Group) - Who: Project leadership, key maintainers, core staff - What: Develops the high-level strategic direction, makes final calls on major â€œnoâ€™s,â€ and shapes the one-page story. This group needs deep context and decision-making authority.
Level 2: Strategic Planning (Medium Group) - Who: Core group + active contributors + key community voices - What: Develops goals, priorities, and focus areas. Provides input on whatâ€™s feasible and what the community needs. This is where you translate strategy into a plan.
Level 3: Input & Feedback (Broad) - Who: Broader community, users, stakeholders - What: Provides insights on needs, pain points, and opportunities. Not involved in final decisions, but their voices inform the strategy. Use surveys, listening sessions, and open feedback channels.
Level 4: Implementation & Tactics (Variable) - Who: Working groups, committees, volunteers who want to be involved - What: Executes on strategic priorities. Once strategy is clear, people can self-organize around implementation within strategic boundaries.




Who has the context and authority to make final strategic decisions for the project?
Who are the people most affected by strategic choices (staff, core volunteers)?
Whose buy-in and support do you need for strategy to actually work?
Which community voices represent important perspectives that might otherwise be missed?
Who wants to be involved in strategic discussions vs.Â who prefers to focus on building/using the software?
Do you have volunteer bandwidth and interest for broad strategic engagement, or is a smaller group more realistic?




Be explicit about roles: Tell people â€œweâ€™re gathering inputâ€ vs.Â â€œweâ€™re making decisions togetherâ€ so expectations are clear.
Create opt-in opportunities: Some volunteers want to help shape strategy; others donâ€™t. Make strategic discussions separate and optional from technical work.
Use a scaffolding approach: Build the support structures (governance, roles, processes) that allow people to contribute strategically at the level that works for them.
Communicate strategy broadly: Even if only a small group develops it, share the strategy widely so everyone understands the direction and can make aligned decisions.





These guides can help you facilitate strategic conversations with your team. Choose the one that fits your current needs, or adapt them to your context.


Use this when your project hasnâ€™t had explicit strategic discussions before.
Part 1: What Problem Are We Solving? (20 min)
Discussion questions: - Whatâ€™s the hard problem our project exists to solve? - Who benefits when we succeed? - What would be lost if our project didnâ€™t exist?
Part 2: What Makes Us Different? (20 min)
Discussion questions: - What are our unique strengths or advantages? - What constraints do we have (resources, capacity, values)? - How can we turn constraints into features of our approach?
Part 3: What Are We NOT Doing? (20 min)
Discussion questions: - What opportunities or requests have we been saying â€˜maybeâ€™ to that donâ€™t fit? - What are we doing now that doesnâ€™t align with our core problem/strength? - What would we need to explicitly say â€˜noâ€™ to in order to succeed?
Part 4: Draft Your One-Page Story (20-30 min)
Work together to complete the one-page story template from the â€œUnderstanding Strategyâ€ section. Donâ€™t worry about perfectionâ€”get something down that you can refine over time.




Use this quarterly or when facing uncertainty to revisit your strategy.
Reflection Questions: - Is our strategy still helping us make decisions more easily? - Have we encountered opportunities we said â€˜yesâ€™ to that didnâ€™t fit our strategy? Why? - Have external conditions changed enough that we need to adapt our approach? - Are we actually saying â€˜noâ€™ to the things we said weâ€™d say no to? - Whatâ€™s one thing we could stop doing to better align with our strategy?




Use this to gather input from your broader community before developing or revising strategy.
Set Clear Expectations Start by explaining that youâ€™re gathering input to inform strategic decisions, and that while you may not be able to act on everything, all perspectives help you understand what matters.
Community Input Questions: - What do you value most about this project? - What pain points or challenges do you face when using or contributing? - What changes or developments in your field/community might affect this project? - If you could wave a magic wand and change one thing about the projectâ€™s direction, what would it be? - What should this project definitely NOT change or compromise on?
After the Session Share back what you heard (themes, not necessarily detailed notes) and how youâ€™ll use it. This builds trust even when you canâ€™t implement every suggestion.




Use this when you need to make sure your strategy reflects your values, especially during uncertain times.
Reflection Questions: - What are the non-negotiable values of this project? (List 3-5) - How does our current strategy/direction reflect those values? - Are there ways weâ€™re compromising our values without realizing it? - What risks are we willing to take to stand by our values? - What risks are we NOT willing to take, given who depends on us? - If staying true to our values means closing some doors, which doors are we okay closing?

Remember: Values-driven strategy can be a source of strength, but it also requires courage. Itâ€™s okay to acknowledge that standing by values feels risky, especially when youâ€™re responsible for other peopleâ€™s livelihoods or community stability.






Use these tools when facing specific strategic decisions. They help you evaluate opportunities and choices against your strategy and values.


Use this when considering whether to pursue a grant, contract, or other funding opportunity.
1. Alignment Check - â˜ Does this funding support work thatâ€™s in our strategy/focus areas? - â˜ If we succeed at what this funding requires, does it advance our core mission? - â˜ Is this work weâ€™d want to do anyway, or are we bending to fit the funding?
2. Values Check - â˜ Does accepting this funding require us to compromise any core values? - â˜ Are there strings attached that would constrain us in problematic ways? - â˜ Does the funderâ€™s reputation align with what we stand for?
3. Capacity Check - â˜ Do we have (or can we hire) the capacity to deliver on this well? - â˜ Will pursuing this pull energy away from higher-priority work? - â˜ Whatâ€™s the opportunity costâ€”what will we NOT do if we take this on?
4. Sustainability Check - â˜ Is this one-time funding or does it build toward longer-term sustainability? - â˜ If itâ€™s time-limited, what happens when it ends? Are we creating dependencies? - â˜ Does this help diversify our funding sources or make us more dependent on one funder?
Decision Framework: - Strong Yes: Aligned on all 4 dimensions - Conditional Yes: 3/4 aligned, with a plan to address concerns - Maybe/Investigate More: 2/4 aligned - No: 0-1/4 aligned, or fundamental values conflict




Use this when you need help deciding whether to decline an opportunity or request.
Q1: Does this align with our stated strategy/focus areas? - If NO â†’ This is likely a strategic â€œnoâ€ - If YES â†’ Continue to Q2
Q2: Do we have capacity to do this well without compromising higher priorities? - If NO â†’ This is a capacity-based â€œnoâ€ (or â€œnot nowâ€) - If YES â†’ Continue to Q3
Q3: Does this align with our values and what we want to be known for? - If NO â†’ This is a values-based â€œnoâ€ - If YES â†’ Continue to Q4
Q4: Are we saying yes because itâ€™s aligned, or because weâ€™re afraid to say no? - If afraid â†’ Pause and discuss with others. Fear of saying no can lead to overcommitment - If truly aligned â†’ This could be a â€œyesâ€
Q5: If we say yes, what are we saying no to? - List what youâ€™ll deprioritize or stop - If the trade-off feels wrong â†’ This might actually be a â€œnoâ€ - If the trade-off makes sense â†’ Proceed with the â€œyesâ€




Use this when youâ€™re considering a significant change in direction.
A â€œPivotâ€ is intentional and strategic: - Youâ€™ve explicitly discussed and decided to change direction - The new direction still aligns with your core mission/problem - You can articulate why the change is necessary - Youâ€™re communicating the change clearly to stakeholders
â€œDriftâ€ is reactive and unintentional: - Youâ€™re taking on work that doesnâ€™t fit your strategy without discussing it - Youâ€™re saying yes to funding/opportunities just because theyâ€™re available - Your team is confused about priorities or direction - You canâ€™t clearly explain why youâ€™re doing certain things
Questions to ask: - Can we articulate why this change advances our mission? - Have we intentionally decided this, or are we just responding to external pressure? - Does our team/community understand and support this shift? - Are we changing our strategy, or are we abandoning it?





These examples come from the community call conversation and illustrate common challenges and insights.


Scenario: â€œWe had early opportunities that brought in money but didnâ€™t advance our goals. It wasnâ€™t leaning into our tailwindsâ€”we were solving a different problem than the one we were supposed to be solving.â€
Insight: Taking funding that doesnâ€™t align with your strategy can pull you off course, even if you need the money. Better to focus limited capacity on opportunities that build toward your goals.




Scenario: â€œYou know you have the right strategy when things feel easyâ€”the decision-making process becomes clearer, even if execution is still hard.â€
Insight: Good strategy acts as a decision-making framework. Team members can reference it to evaluate opportunities independently, which reduces bottlenecks and increases autonomy.




Scenario: â€œWe are very intentional about strategy because our community relies on volunteers and is volunteer-led. Whatever strategy we come up with must have community support and engagement. We start by listening to community voices: what is our community talking about? How are they using our resources? What are their pain points?â€
Insight: For volunteer-driven projects, strategy must emerge from community needs and values. Top-down strategy wonâ€™t work without volunteer buy-in and engagement.




Scenario: â€œA lot of people, including senior and less experienced, would find the act of doubling down on something that is being actively attacked riskyâ€”it takes courage. How do you support people to recognize that itâ€™s a feature that your strategy says no to things?â€
Insight: Standing by values in uncertain times requires courage, especially when youâ€™re responsible for others. Strategy helps by making it clear that saying no to certain things is intentional, not accidental.




Scenario: â€œIt takes a lot of courage to know that [your strategy] will close some doors. We donâ€™t want to be uncomfortable.â€
Insight: A clear strategy inherently limits what you pursueâ€”this is a feature, not a bug. The discomfort of closing doors is a sign that youâ€™re making real strategic choices, not trying to be everything to everyone.




Scenario: â€œVery reactiveâ€”what funding opportunity is coming up or what problem needs fixing. Mostly our challenge here is everyone looking for someone else to set the direction! A combination of burnout and not feeling like individuals have â€˜permissionâ€™ to share a strong opinion.â€
Insight: Without explicit strategy, teams default to reactive mode and wait for others to lead. Creating space for strategic thinking requires both structural changes (time, processes) and cultural changes (permission to have strong opinions).




Scenario: â€œWhen an ED, [think of a] scaffolding metaphorâ€”put up scaffolding that allows you to build the building that you want to. What are you doing in terms of the support structures you build?â€
Insight: Strategy includes thinking about the organizational structures and roles you need to achieve your goals. What scaffolding (governance, hiring, processes) enables your strategy?




Scenario: â€œStrategy thought of as what youâ€™re going to do, but it can also be what youâ€™re not going to do. Has to include what youâ€™re not going to do. Have to be explicit â€˜nos.â€™â€
Insight: Defining what you wonâ€™t do is just as important as defining what you will do. Without explicit boundaries, strategy becomes vague and unhelpful.







Why this happens: Without strategy, everything feels urgent and youâ€™re always reactive.
How to address it: - Start small: dedicate just 30 minutes once a month to strategic reflection - Recognize that some fires exist because you lack strategic clarity - Use the â€œStrategy Check-Inâ€ conversation guide to create regular reflection time - Consider: what fires would you stop having if you had clearer strategy?




Why this happens: Unclear decision-making authority, fear of conflict, burnout, or overly consensus-driven culture without a final decision-maker.
How to address it: - Explicitly designate who has authority to make strategic decisions - Create a â€œsafe to tryâ€ culture where people can propose directions without perfect certainty - Recognize that conflict in service of the project can be generative - Model sharing strong opinions as a leader, even if theyâ€™re not fully formed




Why this happens: Blurry boundaries in open source between users, contributors, staff, and leadership.
How to address it: - Use the â€œLevels of Strategic Engagementâ€ framework from Part 2 - Be explicit about what type of input youâ€™re seeking (information vs.Â decision-making) - Create separate, opt-in opportunities for strategic involvement - Communicate widely even if only a small group decides




Why this happens: External conditions change faster than planning cycles.
How to address it: - Remember: strategy is living and emergent, not a fixed document - Use shorter planning cycles (2 years instead of 5) - Build in regular check-ins to reassess whether strategy still fits - Distinguish between tactical adjustments and fundamental strategic pivots - Give yourself permission to intentionally pivot when conditions warrant it




Why this happens: Resource scarcity and very real financial pressure.
How to address it: - Use the Funding Opportunity Evaluator to systematically assess fit - Recognize that misaligned funding can cost more (in opportunity cost) than it provides - Consider: â€œAre we saying yes because it advances our goals, or just because we need money?â€ - Build toward funding diversification so no single source determines your direction - Remember: â€œThe three jobs of an ED are: donâ€™t run out of money (x3)â€â€”but that doesnâ€™t mean taking every opportunity




Why this happens: Strategy hasnâ€™t been translated into actionable priorities and decision-making frameworks.
How to address it: - Create the â€œone-page storyâ€ that team members can reference - Use strategy in real decisions and explicitly connect the dots: â€œWeâ€™re doing X because of our strategy to Yâ€ - Develop 2-3 focus areas that translate strategy into priorities - Make strategy visible: post it, reference it, â€œtap the signâ€ - Revisit and refine based on how well itâ€™s actually guiding decisions







Books - Good Strategy, Bad Strategy by Richard Rumelt - Key insight: â€œA strategy is not a planâ€ and â€œA strategyâ€™s value is in helping you decide what not to doâ€ - Escaping the Build Trap: How Effective Product Management Creates Value by Melissa Perri - On sticking to strategy when signals tell you to go in other directions
Articles & Talks - Linux Foundation: Setting an Open Source Strategy - FOSDEM 2025: When Is It Right to Say No to Funding? - Hilarious nonprofit funder dynamics video: The Nonprofit Video Every Funder Should Watch




The Carpentries Strategic Plan

Note: Reduced plan to 2 years instead of 5 to account for uncertainty
Focuses on complex goals like inclusivity that arenâ€™t easily measurable







Strategic thinking in open source is different from corporate strategy. Your approach should reflect:

Community-centered values - Strategy must have community support and reflect their needs
Distributed leadership - Many people contribute to direction-setting
Volunteer dynamics - You canâ€™t mandate strategy; people choose to align with it
Resource constraints - Turn limitations into design features
Uncertainty and emergence - Strategy is more like gardening than engineering
Values as strategic assets - Your principles guide what you say yes and no to

Remember: Strategy doesnâ€™t have to be perfect or formal. Even having a rough â€œone-page storyâ€ is better than operating without strategic clarity. Start where you are, involve the right people, and refine over time.




This resource reflects one community conversation and we know thereâ€™s much more to explore. We welcome:

Additional examples and case studies from open source projects
New decision tools and frameworks
Resources that have helped your project think strategically
Feedback on whatâ€™s useful and whatâ€™s missing




This resource was generated as part of CZIâ€™s EOSS Community Calls during late 2024 with Organizational Mycology facilitating discussions, gathering input, and generating the final document. Participants in the calls, and open comment periods are given co-authorship in alphabetical order by last name.

Q4: Are we saying yes because itâ€™s aligned, or because weâ€™re afraid to say no? - If afraid â†’ Pause and discuss with others. Fear of saying no can lead to overcommitment - If truly aligned â†’ This could be a â€œyesâ€
Q5: If we say yes, what are we saying no to? - List what youâ€™ll deprioritize or stop - If the trade-off feels wrong â†’ This might actually be a â€œnoâ€ - If the trade-off makes sense â†’ Proceed with the â€œyesâ€




Use this when youâ€™re considering a significant change in direction.
A â€œPivotâ€ is intentional and strategic: - Youâ€™ve explicitly discussed and decided to change direction - The new direction still aligns with your core mission/problem - You can articulate why the change is necessary - Youâ€™re communicating the change clearly to stakeholders
â€œDriftâ€ is reactive and unintentional: - Youâ€™re taking on work that doesnâ€™t fit your strategy without discussing it - Youâ€™re saying yes to funding/opportunities just because theyâ€™re available - Your team is confused about priorities or direction - You canâ€™t clearly explain why youâ€™re doing certain things
Questions to ask: - Can we articulate why this change advances our mission? - Have we intentionally decided this, or are we just responding to external pressure? - Does our team/community understand and support this shift? - Are we changing our strategy, or are we abandoning it?

title: Strategic Thinking Starter Kit for Open Source Projects
text:
These examples come from the community call conversation and illustrate common challenges and insights.


Scenario: â€œWe had early opportunities that brought in money but didnâ€™t advance our goals. It wasnâ€™t leaning into our tailwindsâ€”we were solving a different problem than the one we were supposed to be solving.â€
Insight: Taking funding that doesnâ€™t align with your strategy can pull you off course, even if you need the money. Better to focus limited capacity on opportunities that build toward your goals.




Scenario: â€œYou know you have the right strategy when things feel easyâ€”the decision-making process becomes clearer, even if execution is still hard.â€
Insight: Good strategy acts as a decision-making framework. Team members can reference it to evaluate opportunities independently, which reduces bottlenecks and increases autonomy.




Scenario: â€œWe are very intentional about strategy because our community relies on volunteers and is volunteer-led. Whatever strategy we come up with must have community support and engagement. We start by listening to community voices: what is our community talking about? How are they using our resources? What are their pain points?â€
Insight: For volunteer-driven projects, strategy must emerge from community needs and values. Top-down strategy wonâ€™t work without volunteer buy-in and engagement.




Scenario: â€œA lot of people, including senior and less experienced, would find the act of doubling down on something that is being actively attacked riskyâ€”it takes courage. How do you support people to recognize that itâ€™s a feature that your strategy says no to things?â€
Insight: Standing by values in uncertain times requires courage, especially when youâ€™re responsible for others. Strategy helps by making it clear that saying no to certain things is intentional, not accidental.




Scenario: â€œIt takes a lot of courage to know that [your strategy] will close some doors. We donâ€™t want to be uncomfortable.â€
Insight: A clear strategy inherently limits what you pursueâ€”this is a feature, not a bug. The discomfort of closing doors is a sign that youâ€™re making real strategic choices, not trying to be everything to everyone.




Scenario: â€œVery reactiveâ€”what funding opportunity is coming up or what problem needs fixing. Mostly our challenge here is everyone looking for someone else to set the direction! A combination of burnout and not feeling like individuals have â€˜permissionâ€™ to share a strong opinion.â€
Insight: Without explicit strategy, teams default to reactive mode and wait for others to lead. Creating space for strategic thinking requires both structural changes (time, processes) and cultural changes (permission to have strong opinions).




Scenario: â€œWhen an ED, [think of a] scaffolding metaphorâ€”put up scaffolding that allows you to build the building that you want to. What are you doing in terms of the support structures you build?â€
Insight: Strategy includes thinking about the organizational structures and roles you need to achieve your goals. What scaffolding (governance, hiring, processes) enables your strategy?




Scenario: â€œStrategy thought of as what youâ€™re going to do, but it can also be what youâ€™re not going to do. Has to include what youâ€™re not going to do. Have to be explicit â€˜nos.â€™â€
Insight: Defining what you wonâ€™t do is just as important as defining what you will do. Without explicit boundaries, strategy becomes vague and unhelpful.

Why this happens: Without strategy, everything feels urgent and youâ€™re always reactive.
How to address it: - Start small: dedicate just 30 minutes once a month to strategic reflection - Recognize that some fires exist because you lack strategic clarity - Use the â€œStrategy Check-Inâ€ conversation guide to create regular reflection time - Consider: what fires would you stop having if you had clearer strategy?




Why this happens: Unclear decision-making authority, fear of conflict, burnout, or overly consensus-driven culture without a final decision-maker.
How to address it: - Explicitly designate who has authority to make strategic decisions - Create a â€œsafe to tryâ€ culture where people can propose directions without perfect certainty - Recognize that conflict in service of the project can be generative - Model sharing strong opinions as a leader, even if theyâ€™re not fully formed




Why this happens: Blurry boundaries in open source between users, contributors, staff, and leadership.
How to address it: - Use the â€œLevels of Strategic Engagementâ€ framework from Part 2 - Be explicit about what type of input youâ€™re seeking (information vs.Â decision-making) - Create separate, opt-in opportunities for strategic involvement - Communicate widely even if only a small group decides




Why this happens: External conditions change faster than planning cycles.
How to address it: - Remember: strategy is living and emergent, not a fixed document - Use shorter planning cycles (2 years instead of 5) - Build in regular check-ins to reassess whether strategy still fits - Distinguish between tactical adjustments and fundamental strategic pivots - Give yourself permission to intentionally pivot when conditions warrant it




Why this happens: Resource scarcity and very real financial pressure.
How to address it: - Use the Funding Opportunity Evaluator to systematically assess fit - Recognize that misaligned funding can cost more (in opportunity cost) than it provides - Consider: â€œAre we saying yes because it advances our goals, or just because we need money?â€ - Build toward funding diversification so no single source determines your direction - Remember: â€œThe three jobs of an ED are: donâ€™t run out of money (x3)â€â€”but that doesnâ€™t mean taking every opportunity




Why this happens: Strategy hasnâ€™t been translated into actionable priorities and decision-making frameworks.
How to address it: - Create the â€œone-page storyâ€ that team members can reference - Use strategy in real decisions and explicitly connect the dots: â€œWeâ€™re doing X because of our strategy to Yâ€ - Develop 2-3 focus areas that translate strategy into priorities - Make strategy visible: post it, reference it, â€œtap the signâ€ - Revisit and refine based on how well itâ€™s actually guiding decisions

title: Strategic Thinking Starter Kit for Open Source Projects
text:
Strategic thinking in open source is different from corporate strategy. Your approach should reflect:

Community-centered values - Strategy must have community support and reflect their needs
Distributed leadership - Many people contribute to direction-setting
Volunteer dynamics - You canâ€™t mandate strategy; people choose to align with it
Resource constraints - Turn limitations into design features
Uncertainty and emergence - Strategy is more like gardening than engineering
Values as strategic assets - Your principles guide what you say yes and no to

Remember: Strategy doesnâ€™t have to be perfect or formal. Even having a rough â€œone-page storyâ€ is better than operating without strategic clarity. Start where you are, involve the right people, and refine over time.
